node.title: New in Paperback: ‘The Fabric of Civilization’ and ‘The National Road’
node.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
node.content: ["WIN ME SOMETHING, by Kyle Lucia Wu. (Tin House, 280 pp., $16.95.) In this debut, a young Chinese-American woman spends nine months nannying for a wealthy white family in TriBeCa, which prompts her to revisit her own tumultuous childhood. \u201cWu\u2019s finely crafted sentences and crisp imagery render visceral Willa\u2019s inner disquiet,\u201d noted our reviewer, YZ Chin.", "EXERCISED: Why Something We Never Evolved to Do Is Healthy and Rewarding, by Daniel Lieberman. (Vintage, 464 pp., $17.) Unlike other fitness books, \u201cExercised\u201d is not trying to sell any diets or fitness plans, our reviewer, Jen A. Miller, observed. Instead, \u201cLieberman, drawing on his expertise and knowledge of the way evolutionary forces work, takes ideas that have been spun and spun again, often based on shaky information, and cracks them open.\u201d", "THE KNOWLEDGE MACHINE: How Irrationality Created Modern Science, by Michael Strevens. (Liveright, 368 pp., $18.95.) \u201cThe Knowledge Machine,\u201d the Times critic Jennifer Szalai wrote, \u201cis ultimately a work of philosophy, and should be considered an ambitious thought experiment.\u201d Strevens, who has a background in mathematics, traces the origins of modern sciences and argues that our obsession with empirical data is both irrational and inhuman.", "THE FABRIC OF CIVILIZATION: How Textiles Made the World, by Virginia Postrel. (Basic, 320 pp., $17.99.) This history of textiles spans millenniums, from Bronze Age civilizations to Tang dynasty China to 16th-century Europe and beyond. According to our reviewer, Dana Thomas, Postrel\u2019s account is \u201ca journey as epic, and varying, as the Silk Road itself.\u201d", "THE LAST ONE, by Fatima Daas. Translated by Lara Vergnaud. (Other Press, 208 pp., $15.99.) This autofiction debut was a literary hit in France, and follows a young, lesbian Algerian woman as she wrestles with the friction of her conflicting identities while living in a majority-Muslim suburb of Paris.", "THE NATIONAL ROAD: Dispatches From a Changing America, by Tom Zoellner. (Counterpoint, 272 pp., $16.95.) Zoellner, the politics editor of The Los Angeles Review of Books, is an \u201cold-fashioned American vagabond,\u201d our reviewer, Jody Rosen, wrote. Observations from Zoellner\u2019s travels, including 30 cross-country road trips over the past two decades, have been collected in this \u201csneakily ambitious book\u201d to present a view of how America\u2019s landscape and its inhabitants have \u201cshaped, and deformed, the other.\u201d"]
